awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Compounding Human and Natural Disasters: Implication on agriculture sectors
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the key sectors being significantly affected by the COVID-19 disaster is the agriculture sector. The COVID-19 human disaster is further posing significant challenges to mitigating ongoing natural disasters (e.g., drought) in different parts of the world, including the USA. COVID-19 will have a significant impact on multiple agricultural sub-sectors as farm prices will be impacted, supply chains will likely slow down, farm workforce disruptions will occur, and the odds of farm bankruptcies will increase. The reduction of demand for crops and the reduction of supply of labor is likely to reduce revenue and increase costs. Drought conditions will further exacerbate the hardship of the broader agricultural sector as water availability declines due to drought and costs continue to rise.The resilience of agricultural systems in the face of natural hazards (e.g., drought, hot days) has improved over the decades but the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic presents a new and unexpected challenge to the farming community. The combination of drought and COVID-19 can lead to a compounding impact on farming sectors. Droughts reduce crop yield and create financial losses, and COVID-19 further compounds this challenge by impacting farm price, supply chains, health risk, and loss of farm work force. This project will study how the combination of ongoing drought and COVID-19 will affect the agricultural sectors that play an important role in the nation's food security. 

The research team will investigate the consequences of compounding drought and COVID 19 on farmers' socio-economic indicators at the county scale, and what strategies can be implemented to minimize the impacts. This project will advance knowledge of the combined influence of human hazard and natural hazard on agricultural sub-sectors and provides an excellent opportunity to study the compounding effect of two different types of hazards in different parts of the USA. Research results will be used to develop strategies for improving awareness about this unique extreme compounding, allowing stakeholders to take precautionary measures for such events in the future. The research findings will be shared with key stakeholders (e.g., Department of Agriculture, agriculture extension specialists) and is targeted to benefit those most affected by this ongoing disaster in the USA and worldwide, assisting in the development of precautionary measures that can be taken in the near future.

This project is jointly funded by the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET) Division and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project studies the relationship between two disasters that may affect agriculture and the food sector: the pandemic and a drought. We developed a conceptual framework and assessed the period between 2019 and 2020.

The pandemic affected agriculture by affecting the labor market and labor availability, which may reduce the capacity to harvest food and ship it. This is indeed what happened during the COVID-19 pandemic. But, altogether, the impact on supply wasn’t that significant. On the other hand, the impact on demand was substantial because consumers shifted from eating in restaurants and other university institutions to eating at home. People were afraid to go to markets. The result was the emergence of a food delivery sector and digitization of the food sector worldwide. Restaurants that could shift to takeout survived, but others went out of business. Service sector workers suffered, especially in countries without government safety nets. Altogether, food security deteriorated, but not as badly as expected, and the food economy adapted quite well to the pandemic despite shortages resulting from reduced supply and transportation problems. The rural sector suffered less in the early period of the pandemic because of less exposure but more later because of lower vaccination rates. 

While a pandemic is a global phenomenon, a drought is local and seriously affects the local economy. If a drought occurs in a major food-growing region, then food prices have global impacts. Having transportation and effective emergency delivery of food relieves the drought pressure, but regions that are not very well connected to the global economy and suffer from transportation barriers may find the drought devastating. International trade and collaboration are important to alleviate drought and pandemic conditions. Collaboration and sharing of information about the virus led to the development of the vaccine, which was distributed globally. Both trade and aid reduced the impact of the drought on regions in Africa that suffered from the pandemic during the drought. Our analysis found that the pandemic, especially in the early days, affected urban sectors worldwide. The drought affected rural sectors in East Africa, other African regions, Australia, Latin America, and the Southern United States. Regions that responded to the pandemic faster through the introduction of social distancing programs performed better than regions that responded more slowly. 

Similarly, early adopters of vaccines were able to perform better. Regions that were more prepared regarding groundwater availability and emergency food supplies could perform better in the drought. The drought and the pandemic have lessons for climate change. Preventative research and adaptation capacity will be essential to address climate change. Delayed response and lack of preparation may be costly. Denial of climate change will be costly, as well as denial of the vaccine. With all these limitations, science-based solutions helped humanity to weather both the pandemic and the vaccine.   

Our funding was used to support graduate students and for data collection.
